1365.05 CLASSIFICATIONS.
   (a)   Heating, Ventilating and Air Conditioning and Refrigeration.
      (1)   Classes of shop registration.
         A.   Heating, ventilating and air conditioning.
            1.   Heating, ventilating and air conditioning contractor's shop
means a certificate which authorizes the holder thereof to engage in the
business of heating, ventilating and air conditioning.
            2.   Heating, ventilating and air conditioning service contractor's
shop means a certificate authorizing the holder thereof to engage in the
business of service and/or repair of heating, ventilating and air conditioning,
excluding refrigeration systems.
         B.   Refrigeration.
            1.   Refrigeration contractor's strop means a certificate which
authorizes the holder thereof to engage in the business of installation,
alteration, replacement or repair of any refrigerating system or any piping,
apparatus, appliance, device or accessory connected therewith.
            2.    Restricted refrigeration contractor's shop means a
certificate which authorizes the holder thereof to engage in the business of
installation, alteration, replacement or repair of portable refrigerating
systems.
      (2)    Classes of certificates of qualification. 
         A.    Heating, ventilating and air conditioning.
            1.    Heating, ventilating and air conditioning contractor means
any person who proceeds with or has charge of laying out or installation,
alteration, replacement or repair of any heating, ventilating and air
conditioning system or any appliance, apparatus, device or accessory connected
to it including precharge refrigeration system. The contractor shall not
install, alter, replace or repair refrigerating systems other than the
precharge type.
            2.    Heating, ventilating and air conditioning mechanic means one
who has learned the trade of heating, ventilating and air conditioning
mechanics and is so qualified as provided for in this chapter to work at such
trade under the supervision or direction of a licensed heating, ventilating and
air conditioning contractor.
            3.    Heating, ventilating and air conditioning service contractor
means any person who proceeds with or has charge of service and/or repair of
heating, ventilating and air conditioning systems or any appliance, apparatus,
device or accessory connected to it excluding refrigerating systems.
            4.    Heating, ventilating and air conditioning service mechanic
means one who has learned the trade of heating, ventilating and air
conditioning service mechanics and is so qualified as provided in this chapter
to work at such trade under the supervision or direction of a licensed heating,
ventilating and air conditioning service contractor.
         B.    Refrigeration.
            1.    Refrigeration contractor means any person who proceeds with
or has charge of the laying out or installation, alteration, replacement or
repair of any refrigerating system or any piping apparatus, appliance, device
or accessory connected therewith. This contractor shall not install, alter,
replace or service heating systems.
            2.    Refrigeration mechanic means one who has learned the trade of
refrigeration mechanics and is so qualified as provided for in this chapter to
work at such trade for or under the direction or supervision of a refrigeration
contractor.
            3.    Restricted refrigeration contractor means any person who
proceeds with or has charge of installation, alteration, replacement or repair
of portable refrigeration systems.
            4.    Restricted refrigeration mechanic means any person who has
learned the trade of portable refrigeration mechanic and is so qualified as
provided for in this chapter to work at such trade for or under the direction
or supervision of a restricted refrigeration contractor.
            5.    Refrigeration operator means any person who qualifies as a
refrigeration mechanic who proceeds with the repair and service of any
refrigeration system and who is a regular and full-time employee of the owner
of such refrigeration system.
   (b)    Electrical.
      (1)    Classes of licenses.
          A.    General electrical contractor means one who possesses, in
addition to the purely mechanical trade knowledge and craftsmanship of a
journeyman electrician, a knowledge of plan making, plan reading and the
ability to lay out in the field electrical installations for all occupancy
classifications.
         B.    Journeyman electrician means one who has learned the trade of
electrician and is so qualified as provided for in this chapter to work at such
trade for or under the supervision of an electrical contractor, either general
or residential.
         C.    Residential electrical contractor means one who possesses a
knowledge of plan making, plan reading and the ability to lay out in the field
electrical installation for one, two and three-family residential occupancies.
         D.    Residential wireman means one who has learned the trade of
electrical wireman and is so qualified as provided for in this chapter to work
at such trade for or under the direction or supervision of a residential
electrician.
         E.    Electrical maintenance contractor means one who has learned the
trade of installing, servicing, maintaining, altering and repairing electric
devices, appliances and equipment.
          F.    Maintenance electrician means one who has learned the trade of
maintenance electrician and is so qualified as provided for in this chapter to
work at such trade for or under the direction or supervision of an electrical
maintenance contractor.
      (2)    Shops.
         A.    General.
            1.    No person, firm or corporation shall display a sign stating
or implying that he, they or it are electrical contractors, or advertise by
means of business cards, stationery, advertisement or trade or telephone
listing or otherwise indicate or represent, orally or in writing that he, they
or it are in the electrical business or trade, unless he, they or it first
obtain a certificate of shop registration as provided by this chapter.
            2.    Nothing in this chapter shall prohibit a general contractor
not registered as herein provided from bidding upon or soliciting electrical
work in connection with the construction, remodeling, alteration or repair of a
building or premises, provided all such work is done by or under the
supervision or direction of a person registered to do such work as provided by
this chapter.
            3.    No person, firm or corporation holding a certificate as
provided herein, shall loan or extend the right or privileges given there;
under for work contracted for or done by any person other than the registrant
or persons working under his direction or supervision and any violation thereof
shall cause such certificate to be suspended or revoked as hereinafter
provided.
         B.    Revocation of certificates. No certificate issued in accordance
with the provisions of this chapter shall be assignable or transferable. Any
such certificate may, after hearing, be suspended or revoked by the
Commissioner, if the person, firm or corporation holding such certificate
willfully, or by reason of incompetence, violates any statutes of the State or
any ordinance, rule or regulation of the City relating to work performed under
requirements or certification.
         C.    Certificates defined.
            1.    Certificate of qualification means a certificate which
authorizes a person, by reason of qualification through an examination, to
install and/or supervise work in accordance with the provisions of this
chapter.
            2.    Certificate of shop registration means a certificate
authorizing a person, firm or corporation through registration and payment of
fees, to engage in the business of operating a shop as defined in this chapter.
         D.    Shop defined.
            1.    "Shop" means a place of business established, equipped,
maintained and operated by an individual, firm or corporation for the purpose
of engaging in and carrying on the work or trade for which they have obtained a
certificate of shop registration.
            2.    A shop must have in its employ a person qualified in the
trade through an examination, as provided for in this chapter. A holder of a
certificate of qualification cannot operate out of more than one shop.
            3.    In the event that the business association with, or
employment of the holder of a certificate of qualification by the shop
terminates, such shop shall become void ten days after such termination except
where another person is designated as the holder of a certificate of
qualification and a new certificate of shop registration is obtained.
         E.    Classes of shop registration.
            1.    General electrical contractors shop means a certificate which
authorizes the holder thereof to engage in the business of installation,
alterations and repair of any electrical wiring device, appliance or equipment
in all occupancy classifications.
            2.    Residential electrical contractor's shop means a certificate
which authorizes the holder thereof to engage in the business of installation,
alteration and repair of any electrical wiring device, appliance or equipment
in one, two and three-family residential occupancies only.
            3.    Electrical maintenance contractor's shop means a certificate
which authorizes the holder thereof to engage in the business of installation,
servicing, maintaining, altering and repairing electric devices, appliances and
equipment and the connection thereof to power outlets provided such connections
are to existing outlets only.
   (c)    Plumbing and Steam Fitting.
      (1)    Classes of licenses.
         A.    Master steamfitter means one who possesses, in addition to the
purely mechanical trade knowledge and craftsmanship of a journeyman, a
knowledge of plan making, plan reading and the ability to layout in the field
steamfitting installations for all occupancy classifications.
         B.    Journeyman steamfitter means one who has learned the trade of a
steamfitter and is qualified as provided in this chapter to work at such trade
for or under the supervision of a master steam fitter.
         C.    Master plumber means one who possesses, in addition to the
purely mechanical trade knowledge craftsmanship of a journeyman plumber, a
knowledge of plan making, plan reading and the ability to layout in the field
plumbing installations for all occupancy classification.
         D.    Journeyman plumber means one who has learned the trade of
plumber, and is so qualified as provided for in this chapter to work at such
trades for or under the supervision of a master plumber.
      (2)    General.
         A.    No person, firm or corporation shall display a sign stated or
implying that he, they or it are plumbers or steam fitters, are advertised by
means of business cards, stationary advertisement or trade or telephone listing
or otherwise indicate orally or in writing that he, they or it are in the
plumbing or steam fitting business or trade unless, he, they or it first obtain
a certificate of shop registration as provided in this chapter.
         B.    Nothing in this chapter shall prohibit a general contractor not
registered as herein provided from bidding upon or soliciting plumbing or steam
fitting work in connection with the construction remodeling, alteration or
repair of a building or premises provided that all such work is done under the
supervision of a person registered to do such work as provided by this chapter.
         C.    No person, firm or corporation holding a certificate as provided
herein shall loan or extend the right or privileges given thereunder for work
contracted or done by any person other than the registrant or persons working
under his direction or supervision and employed by his firm, and any violation
thereof shall cause such certificate to be suspended or revoked as hereinafter
provided.
1365.06 INSURANCE.
   Each applicant for a license shall furnish evidence of insurance for bodily
injury in the amount of one hundred thousand dollars/three hundred thousand
dollars ($100,000/$300,000) and for property damages in the amount of at least
fifty thousand dollars ($50,000).
1365.07 BOND.
   When evidence discloses that the licensee has refused, failed or neglected
to correct or abate violations of any applicable code or ordinance in
performance or any work done pursuant to a license within a reasonable time
after having been notified by the Commissioner of Building and Zoning
Inspection, the Commissioner may require the licensee to furnish a performance
bond in the sum of five thousand dollars ($5,000) guaranteeing full and
faithful compliance by the licensee with all provisions of any applicable code
or ordinance of the City and binding the surety thereon to correct or abate any
violations of any applicable code or ordinance of the City whenever the
applicant for a license named as the principal on such bond refuses, neglects
or fails to correct or abate such violation within a reasonable time limit set
by the Building Commissioner.
1365.08 LICENSING BY THE COMMISSIONER.
   (a)    Upon receipt of a properly completed license application and upon
compliance with all provisions of this chapter the Commissioner of Building and
Zoning Inspection shall issue a license to the applicant which shall be valid
only for the current calendar year or disapprove the application for one of the
several reasons as set forth in Section
1365.09.
 
   (b)    Contractors licensed pursuant to this section shall warrant or be
presumed to have warranted that all work to be performed and all materials to
be supplied by contract are in compliance with all applicable ordinances of the
City unless the contractee has actual knowledge of any deficiencies or
noncompliance at the time the contract is entered into.
1365.09 REVOCATION OR DISAPPROVAL OF LICENSE.
   The Commissioner of Building and Zoning Inspection may disapprove or revoke
any license or renewal thereof issued under the provisions of this chapter for
one or several of the following reasons.
   (a)    Misrepresentation of a material fact by the applicant in obtaining
the license or renewal thereof.
   (b)    The use of the license by the licensee in obtaining a building permit
for work to be performed by a contractor or builder other than the licensee.
   (c)    Violation of or noncompliance with any provisions of any applicable
code or ordinance of the City in the performance of any work done pursuant to a
license issued hereunder.
   (d)    Failure to abate a violation or noncompliance with any provisions of
any applicable code or ordinance of the City within the time specified in the
written notice of such violation or noncompliance.
   (e)    Upon a determination by the Building Commissioner that the applicant
or licensee has engaged in a course of conduct calculated to induce owners and/
or tenants of property or their authorized agents, to enter into a contractual
relationship for labor and/or materials through misrepresentation of labor
costs or that the materials used complied with all applicable ordinances of the
City in which such misrepresentation was made.
   For the purposes of this subsection (e),"course of conduct" is defined as
two or more separate instances of misrepresentation occurring during any twelve
month period.
1365.10 NOTICE OF REVOCATION OR DISAPPROVAL.
   In the event the application for a license is not approved or in the event
any license issued under this chapter is revoked, the applicant shall be
notified of the refusal or revocation in writing and such notice shall be sent
by certified mail to the applicant at the address of the applicant as set forth
in the application for a license. The applicant shall have ten days after
receipt of such notice to appeal such refusal or revocation. Such appeal shall
be perfected by filing a written notice of the appeal with the Commissioner of
Building and Zoning Inspection. Thereupon the applicant shall have not less
than ten days notice of the date and place of the hearing. The appeal shall be
heard by the Board of Appeals, which Board shall have the power after such
hearing to either affirm or overrule the decision of the Commissioner. The
Board shall cause notice of its decision to be sent by certified mail to the
applicant at the address of the applicant as set forth in the application
within thirty days of the date of hearing.
1365.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter is guilty of a misdemeanor of
the third degree. If the offender has previously been convicted of a violation
of this chapter, such second or subsequent offense shall constitute a
misdemeanor of the second degree.
CHAPTER 1369
Registration of Contractors
1369.01   Registration requirement.
1369.02   Application for registration.
1369.03   Time and fee.
1369.04   Insurance.
1369.05   Bond.
1369.06   Registration by Commissioner.
1369.07   Revocation of registration.
1369.08   Notice of denial or revocation.
1369.09   Homeowner’s exemption.
1369.99   Penalty.
 
1369.01 REGISTRATlON REQUIREMENT.
   (a)    No person, corporation, partnership, firm or other business
association acting in the capacity of a contractor shall work at the trade or
occupation of building, constructing, altering, repairing, painting, moving or
demolishing any building, sign or other structure or do any plaster work, mason
work, brick laying, roofing work, paving, or street or sidewalk construction or
repair unless such person, corporation, partnership, firm or other business
association has been duly registered as a contractor by the Division of
Building and Zoning Inspection.
   (b)    "Contractor", for the purpose of this section, means any person,
corporation, partnership, firm or other business association who performs any
work specified above for consideration evidenced by an oral or written
agreement. "Contractor", for purposes of this section shall also mean any
person, firm, corporation or other business association which negotiates a
contract either written or oral for any work specified above, but does not
perform physical labor to complete the work as set forth in the contract. No
corporation, partnership, firm or other business association shall engage in
work for which a certificate of registration is required, unless at least one
responsible member, officer or employee of such corporation, partnership, firm
or other business association has been registered pursuant to this chapter. All
work performed by such corporation, partnership, firm or other business
association shall be under the direct supervision of the registered person.
   (c)    A person, corporation, firm or other business association acting in
the capacity of a contractor and performing more than one type of work as set
forth in subsection (a) hereof, shall only be required to register once
annually as a contractor regardless of the number and types of work performed.
1369.02 APPLICATlON FOR REGISTRATlON.
   (a)    Applicants for registration shall apply at the office designated by
the Commissioner of Building and Zoning Inspection and make application for
registration on a form provided by the Commissioner.
   (b)    If the application is for a firm, partnership, corporation or other
business association the application shall contain the names and addresses of
all members or officers, as the case may be. The application shall also contain
such other relevant information as the Commissioner deems necessary.
   (c)    The applicant shall have a minimum of five years practical experience
and an affidavit to this effect shall be provided.
1369.03 TIME AND FEE.
   The registration shall be valid for the calendar year in which issued and
shall be renewed annually thereafter. A fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00)
shall be paid at the time of the original issuance and a fee of forty dollars
($40.00) thereafter for each renewal. The fee to renew a license that has
expired shall be the same as the cost of a new license. All licenses expire on
December 31st, of the year in which the license was issued.
(Ord. 182-2006. Passed 12-11-06.)
1369.04 INSURANCE.
   Each applicant for a certificate of registration shall furnish evidence of
insurance for bodily injury in the amount of one hundred thousand dollars/three
hundred thousand dollars ($100,000/$300,000), and for property damages in the
amount of at least fifty thousand dollars ($50,000) if the applicant acts as a
contractor for a continuous period of three months or more per calendar year.
1369.05 BOND.
   When evidence discloses that the registrant has refused, failed or neglected
to correct or abate violations of any applicable code or ordinance in
performance of work done pursuant to a certificate of registration within a
reasonable time after having been notified by the Commissioner of Building and
Zoning Inspection, the Commissioner may require the registrant to furnish a
performance bond in the amount of ten thousand dollars ($10,000) guaranteeing
full and faithful compliance by the applicant with all provisions of any
applicable code or ordinance of the City whenever the applicant for
registration named as the principal on such bond refuses, neglects or fails to
correct or abate such violation within a reasonable time set by the
Commissioner.
1369.06 REGISTRATION BY COMMISSIONER.
   (a)    Upon receipt of a properly completed application form and compliance
with Sections
1369.03 to
1369.05, the Commissioner of Building and Zoning Inspection shall register the
applicant in a journal kept for that purpose, and shall issue to the registrant
a certificate of registration valid only for the current calendar year. The
registration shall expire on December 31 of each year and may be renewed from
year to year.
   (b)    Contractors registered pursuant to this section shall warrant or be
presumed to have warranted that all work performed and all materials to be
supplied by contract are in compliance with all applicable ordinances of the
City unless the contractee has actual knowledge of any deficiencies or
noncompliance at the time the contract is entered into.
1369.07 REVOCATION OF REGISTRATION
   The Commissioner of Building and Zoning Inspection may disapprove or revoke
any certificate of registration or renewal thereof issued under provisions of
this chapter for one or several of the following reasons:
   (a)    Misrepresentation of a material fact by the applicant in obtaining
the certificate of registration or renewal thereof.
(b)    The use of the certificate of registration by the registrant in
obtaining a building permit for work to be performed by a contractor or builder
other than the registrant.
   (c)    Violation of or noncompliance with any provision of any applicable
code or ordinance of the City in the performance of any work done pursuant to
the certificate issued hereunder.
   (d)    Failure to abate a violation or noncompliance with any provision of
any applicable code or ordinance of the City within the time specified in the
written notice of such violation or noncompliance.
   (e)    Upon a determination by the Commissioner that the applicant or
registrant has engaged in a course of conduct calculated to induce owners and/
or tenants of property or their authorized agents, to enter into a contractual
relationship for labor and/or materials through misrepresentation of labor
costs or that the materials used complied with all applicable ordinances of the
City in which such misrepresentation was made.
   For the purposes of this subsection (e), "course of conduct" is defined as
two or more separate instances of misrepresentation occurring during any twelve
month period.
1369.08 NOTICE OF DENIAL OR REVOCATION.
   In the event the application for a certificate is not approved, or in the
event any certificate issued under this chapter is revoked, the applicant shall
be notified of the refusal or revocation in writing and such notice shall be
sent by certified mail to the applicant at the address of the applicant as set
forth in the application for a certificate. The applicant shall have ten days
after receipt of such notice to appeal such refusal or revocation. Such appeal
shall be perfected by filing a written notice of the appeal with the
Commissioner of Building and Zoning Inspection. Thereupon, the applicant shall
have not less than ten days notice of the date and place of the hearing. The
appeal shall be heard by the Board of Appeals, which Board shall have the power
after such hearing to either affirm or overrule the decision of the
Commissioner. The Board shall cause notice of its decision to be sent by
certified mail to the applicant at the address of the applicant as set forth in
the application within thirty days of the date of hearing.
 
1369.09 HOMEOWNER'S EXEMPTION.
   Nothing contained in this chapter or in any regulation adopted pursuant to
this chapter, shall be construed to require that the owner of any residential
property shall be licensed or required to hold a certificate of registration to
perform work upon such property. The owner, performing such work may hire
persons not included in the definition of contractor to assist in such work,
provided that he notifies the authority enforcing this chapter of his intention
to hire unregistered help prior to the issuance of the building or zoning
permit and that he furnishes to such authority upon demand the identity of the
person or persons hired, together with an accurate account of the hours worked
and moneys paid to such person or persons, for the purpose of establishing the
contractor status of the person or persons so engaged. Such work shall be done
in conformity with the provisions of this Building Code and any rules and
regulations promulgated thereunder and no work shall be done unless all
permits, inspections and approvals required by this Building Code are first
secured.
1369.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter shall be guilty of a
misdemeanor of the third degree. If the of fender has been previously convicted
of a violation of this chapter, such second or subsequent offense shall
constitute a misdemeanor of the second degree.
CHAPTER 1375
Appeals
1375.01    Established; membership.
1375.02   Advisory opinions.
1375.03    Appeal and review; fee.
 
1375.01 ESTABLISHED; MEMBERSHIP.
      (a)    The Board of Zoning Appeals is hereby designated as the appeals
board for any matters pertaining to Part Thirteen of the Codified Ordinances of
the City of Oregon, Ohio, and the Residential Code of Ohio. The Board is
precluded from hearing any matter that pertains to the Ohio Building Code
except as otherwise provided by law.
(Ord. 069-2012. Passed 6-11-12.)
 
   (b)    The Board shall adopt its own rules and regulations of procedure and
keep a record of its proceedings which shall show the action taken by the Board
and the vote of each member present upon each question considered.
Interpretations of codes made by the Board and policies established by the
Board, where the same are not otherwise provided by law, shall be binding upon
the Division of Building and Zoning Inspection. Three votes shall be required
to establish every decision of the Board. (A.O.)
 
   (c)   The Board shall meet at the request of the Commissioner or any Board
member. All meetings shall be open to the public.
 
   (d)    The Board shall hear and decide appeals de novo, and shall review on
appeal, any order, requirement, determination or decision made by the Division
of Building and Zoning Inspection as it pertains to Part 13 of the Codified
Ordinances of Oregon, Ohio and the Residential Code of Ohio.
(Ord. 069-2012. Passed 6-11-12.)
1375.02 ADVISORY OPINIONS.
   Upon the request of the Division of Building and Zoning Inspection, the
Board may render advisory opinions upon any matter within the jurisdiction of
the Division and may make recommendations to the various branches and
departments of the City pertaining to matters within the jurisdiction of the
Board.
1375.03 APPEAL AND REVIEW; FEE.
   Except as otherwise provided by law, any applicant for a license or permit
which has been denied or which has been suspended or revoked by the Division of
Building and Zoning Inspection shall have the right to appeal such denial,
suspension or revocation. The appeal shall be filed with the Division within
seven business days of the denial, suspension or revocation or notice thereof,
and shall be accompanied by a fee of ten dollars ($10.00) for processing the
appeal. The Division shall transmit the file relating to the matter to the
Board of Appeals and shall be represented at the hearing of the appeal by a
member of the Division as the Commissioner may direct, or as may be otherwise
provided by law. The Division shall serve written notice, personally or by
registered or certified mail, upon the applicant of the time, place and date of
the hearing on the appeal and the same shall be set for the next regular
meeting of the Board of Appeals providing that such date permits two days'
notice thereof to the appellant, and providing further that the appellant may
waive written notice in order to expedite hearing of the appeal. The appellant
may appear and be heard in person, or by counsel. Failure to appear at the
hearing shall be deemed to be a withdrawal of the appeal, unless prior thereto,
the appellant has, through the Division requested a continuance. Any order,
requirement, determination or decision of the Division may be appealed in like
manner.

CHAPTER 1501
Bureau of Fire Prevention

133

1501.01 CHIEF; DISTRICT CHIEF; INSPECTORS.
   There is hereby established in the Fire Division of the City, hereinafter
referred to as the Bureau of Fire Prevention, hereinafter called the "Bureau, "
consisting of a Chief hereinafter referred to as the "Chief, " a District
Chief, hereinafter referred to as the "District Chief, " and not more than ten
fire prevention inspectors. The Chief of the Fire Division shall be Chief of
the Bureau of Fire Prevention. Each fire prevention inspector shall join the
station in whichever district he resides and his membership shall be above the
regular number now carried by the station. He shall be governed by all rules of
the Fire Division and remain in good standing at his station. In the Fire
Fighting Service, he shall carry the rank of District Chief and follow in the
chain of command the same as the second responding district or if more than a
one-station alarm, rank as the last responding District Chief.
(Ord. 65-1970. Passed 5-11-70.)
 
1501.02 MEMBERS.
   The Chief shall from time to time designate from among the members of the
Division a District Chief and such fire prevention inspectors as he and the
Mayor or his designee deem necessary for proper enforcement of this chapter.
(Ord. 164-1966. Passed 11-28-66.)
1501.03 DUTIES.
   It shall be the duty of the officers and inspectors of the Bureau to make
inspections, promote safety practices, conduct educational fire prevention
programs, minimize fire hazards and assist in enforcing all laws and ordinances
of the City in relation to fire prevention and fire hazards, including but not
limited to the following:
   (a)    The prevention of fires and abatement of existing fire hazards.
   (b)    The storage and use of explosives and inflammables.
   (c)    The installation, adequacy and maintenance of automatic and other
fire alarm systems and fire extinguishing equipment.
   (d)    The maintenance, adequacy and regulation of fire escapes.
   (e)    The means and adequacy of exit in the case of fire from factories,
schools, hotels, lodging houses, rest homes, hospitals, churches, halls,
theaters, amphitheaters and all other places in which numbers of persons work,
live or congregate, from time to time, for any purpose.
   (f)   The investigation of the cause, origin and circumstances attending
fires whether or not the Fire Division has been summoned to extinguish the
same.
   The members of the Bureau shall have such other powers and perform such
other duties consistent with the laws of Ohio and ordinances of the City as may
be conferred and
imposed upon them from time to time by the Chief or the Mayor or his designee.
In the absence of or during the disability of the Chief of the Bureau, the
District Chief of the Bureau shall perform the duties of and be vested with the
powers and authority of the Chief if so ordered by the Mayor.
(Ord. 164-166. Passed 11-28-66.)
1501.04 ACTIVITIES REQUIRING A PERMIT.
   Any person, firm or corporation engaging in any one or more of the following
activities shall secure a permit as hereinafter provided:
   (a)    Maintaining or operating a gasoline filling station.
   (b)    Maintaining or operating a public garage.
   (c)    Use, storage, handling and/or transportation of:
      (1)    Explosives,
      (2)    Calcium carbide or acetylene,
      (3)    Liquefied petroleum gases,
      (4)    Flammable liquid except as contained in approved tanks for fuel
and storage only of paints, lacquers and finishes in sealed containers.
   (d)    Maintenance or operation of welding equipment.
   (e)    Maintenance or operation of enclosed spray paint facilities.
   (f)    Maintenance or operation of stoves, ranges, hot plates, broilers,
grease hoods and vents other than residential.
   (g)    Storage or use of combustible packing material or combustible
shipping containers.
   (h)    Operations using or producing sawdust, grain dust or other
combustible dusts or particles or combustible plastics or resins.
   (i)    Installation of inflammable decorations of any kind in buildings or
premises used for trade or business or listed in Section
1501.03(e).
   (j)    Maintaining a rest home or convalescent home, provided that nothing
contained in this chapter shall be construed to apply to:
       (1)    The transportation of any article or thing shipped in conformity
with regulations prescribed by the Interstate Commerce Commission.
       (2)    The military or naval forces of the United States.
   (k)    Maintaining or operating motion picture projection facilities.
(Ord. 164-1966. Passed 11-28-66.)
 
1501.05 INSPECTION PRIOR TO PERMIT ISSUANCE; TERM.
    Before any permit required by Section
1501.04 may be issued, the Chief, District Chief or the Chief's duly authorized
inspector shall inspect and approve the receptacles, vehicles, buildings,
premises or storage places to be used for any such purpose. If the Chief finds
and determines that any person, firm or corporation required to secure such a
permit is in observance of proper precautions and safety practices in respect
to the activity or activities specified in Section
1501.04, one permit may be issued to such person covering all such activities
conducted within the City.
   Application for such permit shall be made at the office of the Mayor or his
designee within thirty days after the date that applicant becomes subject to
the provisions of this chapter upon forms prescribed by such officer.
   A permit will be issued for a period of not more than one year as the Mayor
or his designee may deem appropriate to the operation or material covered
thereby. All permits shall expire on March 31 next following their issuance. No
fee will be required for such permits.
(Ord. 164-1966. Passed 11-28-66.)
1501.06 PLACES TO BE INSPECTED.
   The Chief shall inspect or cause to be inspected by an officer or inspector
of the Bureau as deemed necessary by the Mayor or his designee:
   (a)    All premises in which any activity mentioned in Section
1501.04 is carried on and all buildings, machinery and equipment in which or by
which especially hazardous manufacturing processes, storages or installations
of acetylene or other gases, chemicals, oils, explosives and inflammable
materials are used, stored or carried on;
   (b)    All interior fire alarm and automatic sprinkling systems and such
other appliances as the Chief designates;
    (c)    All buildings, premises and public places in the commercial,
industrial and closely built-up sections of the City, except the interior of
private dwellings; and,
   (d)    All school and public buildings, motels, rest homes, convalescent
homes and hospitals,
for the purpose of ascertaining and causing to be corrected any conditions
creating or constituting a fire hazard or in violation of any ordinance of the
City or law of the State pertaining to the protection of life and property from
fire or in the event of fire.
(Ord. 164-1966. Passed 11-28-66.)
1501.07 ORDER TO CORRECT OR CHANGE CONDITIONS.
   Whenever an inspection by any authorized member of the Bureau or other
officer of the City discloses that:
   (a)    Inflammable or combustible material is not arranged, stored or used
in any building or upon any premises in conformity with existing law, ordinance
or permit, or in such a manner as to afford reasonable safety against the
danger of fire or in the event of fire, or is so stored or arranged as to
impede or prevent access to any exits from any premises in case of fire; or
   (b)    Fire escapes, fire doors, fire alarms, fire extinguishing equipment
or appliances or other equipment for the prevention, extinguishing or warning
of fires are wholly wanting or inadequate in number, condition, size,
arrangement or efficiency for the reasonable protection of such premises and
the occupants thereof or of adjoining property and occupants of the same or the
public against fire or in the event of fire; or
   (c)    By reason of age, dilapidation or other cause any building, structure
or premises or equipment thereon is particularly susceptible to the incidence
or spread of fire or is in such condition or so situated as to endanger other
property, the occupants thereof or the public in the event of fire,
the Chief may, by written order directed and served as provided in Section
1501.08, order the removal or rearrangement of materials mentioned in
subsection (a) hereof, the installation, replacement or repair of the equipment
or appliances mentioned in subsection (b) hereof, or the repair, relocation or
removal of the buildings or structures mentioned in subsection (c) hereof and/
or revocation of any permit issued under the provisions of Section
1501.05 to the extent deemed necessary or expedient for the reasonable
protection of the premises involved, occupants thereof, adjoining property and
occupants of the same and the general public.
(Ord. 164-1966. Passed 11-28-66.)
 
1501.08 SERVICE OF ORDER; COMPLIANCE TIME LIMIT.
   The order referred to in Section
1501.07 may be directed to the owner, lessee or occupant of such premises or
the person in charge or control thereof if not the owner, lessee or occupant,
or the person in charge or control of the articles, materials, goods, wares,
merchandise, equipment or appliances referred to in such section or to the
owner thereof as the circumstances may require and shall be served upon such
owner, lessee, occupant or person in charge or control personally. In case no
such person is found upon the premises, service may be had by posting a copy of
the order in a conspicuous place, such as a door or other entrance to the
premises. If the owner or lessee is a nonresident of the City, a copy of the
order shall be sent by certified mail to the last known post office address of
such person.
   Compliance with the order shall be made by the owner, lessee, occupant or
person in charge within twenty-four hours of the service of such notice, unless
within such period the party upon whom such service is made appeals to the
Mayor or his designee, who shall within five days review such order and
approve, modify or revoke the order. If approved or modified, compliance
therewith shall be made within the time fixed by the Mayor. The person being so
served shall not fail to comply with such order within the twenty-four hour
period or the time fixed by the Mayor after appeal.
(Ord. 164-1966. Passed 11-28-66.)
1501.09 RIGHT OF ENTRY.
   The Chief, District Chief or any authorized inspector of the Bureau may at
all reasonable hours enter any building or premises for the purpose of making
any inspection or investigation authorized by law or under the provisions of
the ordinances of the City.
(Ord. 164-1966. Passed 11-28-66.)
1501.10 SUPERVISION OF FIRE DRILLS IN SCHOOLS.
   The Chief, in cooperation with duly authorized officers of the State, shall
require and supervise fire drills in each and every public, private or
parochial school and educational institution within the City and shall make
certain by regulations and inspections that all doors and exits in such
buildings shall be kept unlocked during school hours or when the same are being
used and occupied for any other purpose.
(Ord. 164-1966. Passed 11-28-66.)
1501.11 RECORDS OF FIRES.
   The Bureau, under the direction of the Chief, shall keep a record of all
fires and of the facts and circumstances concerning the same, including
statistics as to the cause, nature and extent of such fires, the damage caused
thereby and whether or not loss or damage thereby is covered by insurance and
the amount so covered. Such records shall be made daily and shall be open to
public inspection.
(Ord. 164-1966. Passed 11-28-66.)
1501.12 ANNUAL REPORT.
   On or before January 15 of each year, the Bureau shall prepare and submit to
the Mayor or his designee, an annual report of the activities of the Bureau,
containing such information and statistics as the Director prescribes.
(Ord. 164-1966. Passed 11-28-66.)
1501.13 PROVISIONS ARE SUPPLEMENTARY.
   The provisions and requirements of this chapter shall be in addition to and
not in contravention or limitation of the laws of the State or the powers and
authority of the Chief or members of the Bureau granted or conferred thereby.
(Ord. 164-1966. Passed 11-28-66.)
1501.99 PENALTY.
   Any person, individual or corporation violating any provision of this Part
Fifteen Fire Prevention Code or failing, refusing or neglecting to comply with
any order issued pursuant to any provision of this Code, for which no penalty
is otherwise provided, shall be fined not more than five hundred dollars
($500.00) and in addition thereto not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00)
for each day such violationis permitted to exist.
   In addition to the foregoing penalties, in case of fire resulting directly
or indirectly from any violation of this Part Fifteen - Fire Prevention Code or
any other ordinance of the City, or any omission or neglect to properly comply
with a lawful written order of the Chief issued pursuant to Section
1501.07, the person or persons responsible for the violation thereof shall be
liable to the City in a civil action for all cost and expense of the Fire
Division incurred in the extinguishment of any such fire or response to an
alarm by reason thereof, including expense of employees and the use of
equipment, apparatus and materials, such cost and expense to be computed and
fixed by the Mayor or his designee.
(Ord. 164-1966. Passed 11-28-66.)
CHAPTER 1509
Ohio Fire Code
1509.01   Adoption; purpose.
1509.02   File and distribution copies.
1509.03   Amendments.
1509.04   Additional requirements.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Adoption of technical codes by reference - see Ohio R.C. 731.231
Fire lanes - see FIRE PREV. Ch.
1519
 
1509.01 ADOPTION; PURPOSE.
   There is hereby adopted and incorporated by reference as if set out at
length herein for the purpose of prescribing regulations governing conditions
hazardous to life and property from fire or explosion the 2007 Ohio Fire Code
(OFC) and also any amendments, modifications, revisions or changes as may from
time to time be adopted by the State of Ohio which contain the most recent
additions, amendments and revisions to Article 1301:7 of the Ohio
Administrative Code are subject to the amendments provided under Section
1509.03 of this Code.
(Ord. 101-2008. Passed 6-9-08.)
1509.02 FILE AND DISTRIBUTION COPIES.
   A complete copy of the Ohio Fire Code adopted under Section
1509.01 is on file with the Clerk of Council for inspection by the public. The
Clerk of Council also has copies available for distribution to the public at
cost.
(Ord. 38-1982. Passed 6-14-82.)
1509.03 AMENDMENTS.
   The Ohio Fire Code (OFC) adopted under Section
1509.01 is modified by the enactment, amendment or deletion of the following
provisions:
CHAPTER 1301:7-7-01 PERMITS AND INSPECTION FEE, GENERAL
 
   (L)   Section 112 - Fire Marshal Permits and Inspection Fees is hereby
replaced in its entirety with the following:
Permits and inspection fees required. Except for those permits which are
expressly issued by the State Fire Marshal, all permits specified in this Code
will be issued by the Bureau of Fire Prevention. The Bureau of Fire Prevention
shall require reasonable fees for such permits. Permits shall at all times be
kept on the premises designated therein and shall at all times be subject to
inspection by the Bureau of Fire Prevention. The Bureau of Fire Prevention
shall require inspection fees as follows:
      (1)   ANNUAL FIRE PREVENTION INSPECTIONS FEES:
         1.   Paint spray shops: Auto body shops and other commercial
enterprises engaged in spray painting operations must pay an annual fire
prevention inspection fee of fifty dollars ($50.00).
         2.   Bowling establishments:
            (A)   Engaged in refinishing operations involving the use of
flammable liquids must pay an annual fire prevention inspection fee of fifty
dollars ($50.00) plus the area fees under item #6 below.
            (B)   Not engaged in pin refinishing operations must pay an annual
area fees under Item #6 below.
         3.   Dry cleaning plants must pay an annual fee as follows based on
flashpoint of solvents used as follows:
            Type III B w/Flashpoint >299 degrees    $50.00
            Type IIIA w/Flashpoint - 140 to 200 degrees 60.00
            Type II w/Flashpoint < 100 degrees    70.00
         4.   Dust explosion hazards: Grain elevators, flour, starch or feed
mills or plants pulverizing aluminum, coal, cocoa, magnesium, spices, sugar or
other material producing dust which if mixed with air in the proper proportions
becomes explosive, but shall not include the electrical power plants, must pay
an annual fire prevention inspection fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00).
         5.   Lumber yards and wood working plants which use or store more than
100,000 board feet of lumber must pay an annual fire prevention inspection fee
of one hundred dollars ($100.00).
         6.   Public Assembly: All theaters, dance halls, public rental halls,
skating rinks, dining establishments and other places of assembly accommodating
more than 100 or more persons must pay an annual fee in accordance with the
following schedule:
 
Square Feet Area    Cost
1 to 2,500         $ 75.00
2,501 to 5,000       100.00
5,001 to 10,000       200.00
Over 10,000          250.00
         7.   Vehicle Filling Stations: Any place, building, pump or device
operated and maintained upon any public street, highway or place in the City
where gasoline or other motor fuels are kept for sale, at retail, to the public
must pay an annual fire prevention inspection fee of fifty dollars ($50.00),
plus an additional three dollars ($3.00) for each nozzle; more than four
nozzles, located on the premises.
         8.   Storage of Motor Fuels: Any place, building, pump or device
operated and maintained on private property where gasoline or other motor fuels
are stored and dispensed for private consumption must pay an annual fire
prevention inspection fee of fifty dollars ($50.00).
         9.   Marine Service Stations: Same as #7 Vehicle Filling Stations
above.
         10.   Vehicle Repair Garages which do not dispense, sell or store
gasoline in quantity consumptions must pay an annual fire prevention inspection
fee of fifty dollars ($50.00).
         11.   Automobile wrecking yards, junk yards and waste material
handling plants consumption must pay an annual fire prevention inspection fee
of fifty dollars ($50.00).
         12.   Combustible Gases: Any person, firm or corporation storing,
handling or using at normal temperatures and pressures more than 2,000 cubic
feet of flammable compressed gas or 6,000 cubic feet of non-flammable
compressed gas in conjunction with welding or cutting operations must pay an
annual fire prevention inspection fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00).
         13.   Combustible Fibers: Any person, firm or corporation involved in
the equipment, process and operation for handling, storage or use of
combustible vegetable or animal fibers including, among others, readily
ignitable and free burning fibers such as cotton, sisal, henequen, ixtle, jute,
hemp, tow, cocoa fiber, oakum, baled waste paper, kapok, hay, stray, Spanish
moss, excelsior, certain synthetic fibers and cloth, scraps in quantities in
excess of 100 cubic feet must pay an annual fire prevention inspection fee of
one hundred dollars ($100.00).
         14.   Wholesale paint stores engaged in handling, dispensing, storage,
use or sale of bulk flammable liquids must pay an annual fire prevention
inspection fee of seventy dollars ($70.00).
         15.   Retail paint stores engaged in storing, handling, use or sale of
bulk flammable liquids must pay an annual fire prevention inspection fee of
fifty dollars ($50.00).
         16.   Wholesale Bulk Stations: Any place where flammable liquids are
stored in quantities, or from which they are sold at wholesale or delivered
into tank trucks or tank cars. Such places shall include marine terminals or
plants where flammable liquids are blended, but shall not include oil
refineries, paint plants, or places where tanks are installed for use
exclusively for the storage of fuel oil for use upon the premises. Wholesale
bulk stations must pay an annual fire prevention inspection fee of one hundred
dollars ($100.00).
         17.   Paint factories must pay an annual fire prevention inspection
fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00).
         18.   Sign shops in silkscreen operations must pay an annual fire
prevention inspection fee of fifty dollars ($50.00).
         19.   Chemical manufacturing and storage facilities must pay an annual
fire prevention inspection fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00).
         20.   Hazardous Material and Chemicals: Any person, firm or
corporation storing, handling more than fifty-five (55) gallons of corrosive
liquids, or more than five hundred (500) pounds of oxidizing materials, or more
than ten (10) pounds of organic peroxides, or more than five hundred pounds of
nitro methane, or one thousand (1,000) pounds or more of ammonium nitrate,
ammonium nitrate fertilizers and fertilizer mixtures or any amount of highly
toxic material or poisonous gas, or the storing, handling of any installation
of more than one micro curie of radium not contained in a sealed source or any
amount of radioactive material in a sealed source or sources, or any amount of
radioactive material for which a specific license from the United States Atomic
Energy Commissioner (AEC) is required in accordance with nationally recognized
good practice, must pay an annual fire prevention inspection fee of one hundred
dollars ($100.00).
         21.   Liquefied Petroleum Gases: Any person, firm or corporation
storing, liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) in containers having a capacity in
excess of 299 gallons must pay an annual fire prevention inspection fee of
fifty dollars ($50.00), plus two dollars ($2.00) per each 100 gallons of
capacity over 2,000 gallons. If the capacity exceeds 5,000 gallons, a flat rate
annual fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00) must be paid.
         22.   Magnesium processing: Any person, firm or corporation engaging
in melting casting, heat treating, machining or grinding more than ten (10)
pounds of magnesium per working day must pay an annual fire prevention
inspection fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00).
         23.   Material Storage: Any person storing in any building or upon any
premises 2,500 cubic feet (70 m3) gross volume of combustible empty packing
cases, barrels or similar containers, or rubber tires, balled cotton, rubber,
cork, or other similarly combustible material shall pay an annual fire
prevention inspection fee of fifty dollars ($50.00).
         24.   Cellulose Nitrate (Pyroxlyin) Plastics: Any retailers, jobbers
and wholesalers storing or handling more than 25 pounds (11.35 kg) of cellulose
nitrate (pyroxylin) plastics shall pay an annual fire prevention inspection fee
of fifty dollars ($50.00).
         25.   Hazardous Production Materials. Any person, firm or corporation
storing, handling or using hazardous production materials shall pay an annual
fire prevention inspection fee of fifty dollars ($50.00).
         26.   Cryogenic Liquids: Any person, firm or corporation engaged in
the production, storage, or sale of cryogenic liquids shall pay an annual fire
prevention inspection fee of fifty dollars ($50.00).
         27.   Organic Coatings: Any person, firm or corporation engaged in a
manufacturing operation making more than 1 gallon (0.00379 m3) of an organic
coating on any working day shall pay an annual fire prevention inspection fee
of fifty dollars ($50.00).
         28.   Heliport, Airports: Any facility operated for the storage,
landing and refueling of helicopters and airports shall pay an annual fire
prevention inspection fee of fifty dollars ($50.00).
All annual fire prevention permits must be paid annually for each separate
location within the City and are due by July 1. Payment shall be made to the
Oregon Fire Department. After July 30, permit fees are considered delinquent
and subject to a 25 percent penalty.

      (3)   SCHEDULE OF BUREAU OF FIRE PREVENTION PERMIT FEES FOR EXPLOSIVES
AND FIREWORKS.
         1.   Blasting: Any person, firm or corporation doing blasting shall,
prior to issuance of a permit, file a bond deemed adequate in each case by the
Bureau of Fire Prevention, which bond shall be available for payment of any
damages arising from the permitted blasting and coincidental with posting of
bond, payment for a fire prevention inspection fee of one hundred dollars
($100.00).
         2.   Fireworks: The permittee shall post a bond in an amount deemed
adequate by the Chief of the Fire Prevention Bureau for payment of all damages
which may be caused either to a person or persons or to property by reason of
the permitted display, and arising from any acts of the permittee, his agents,
employees or subcontractors. Coincidental with posting bonds, payment of a fire
prevention inspection fee of seventy-five dollars ($75.00) is required.
Payment of the above listed fees shall be made to the Bureau of Fire Prevention
and must be paid before plans are approved and at the time of application.
      (4)   ADDITIONAL PERMITS:
The Mayor, the Chief of the Fire Division and the Chief of the Fire Prevention
Bureau shall act as a committee on determination, and specify any new
materials, processes, or occupancies, and trades which constitute a fire hazard
which shall require permits, in addition to those now enumerated in this code.
The Chief of The Fire Prevention Bureau shall publish annually in a conspicuous
place in this office, and shall also maintain in his office details and
descriptive drawings showing approved and acceptable methods of storing,
handling or protecting such materials as shall be deemed to require a permit.
   (H)   Section 108 Appeal of Orders is hereby replaced in its entirety with
the following:
APPEALS: Appeals to the board may be taken by any person aggrieved by any
decision or interpretation of the Bureau of Fire Prevention made under the
provisions of this code.
The Mayor, upon receipt of such appeal, shall call the meeting of the Board of
Appeals on Fire Prevention, which Board shall consist of the Mayor, who shall
serve as chairman, Director of Public Service, and Director of Law or their
delegates. Within ten days from the receipt of such appeal, investigation into
the facts to determine if the notice, order of abatement, decision or refusal
to issue a permit by the Chief of the Bureau of Fire Prevention is in
accordance with the provisions or intent of this Code and shall reverse or
revoke or modify the notice, order of abatement, decision or refusal to issue a
permit, the same shall remain in full force and effect.
The Board of Appeals on Fire Prevention shall give notice in writing to the
affected parties of this approval, revocation or modification of the notice,
order of abatement or refusal to issue a permit, and if its decision
constitutes an approval, such notification shall contain a statement as to the
time within which the notice or order shall be complied with.
CHAPTER 1301:7-7-05 FIRE SERVICE FEATURES
 
   (H)   Section 508 Fire Protection Water Supplies.
      (a)   508.5.1 Where required is hereby replaced in its entirety with the
following:
   Hydrants: If major portion of any building is over 400 feet from City water
main and hydrants, the owner shall provide hydrants on his property at
locations designated by the Chief of Fire Prevention Bureau. The measurement of
distance shall be along the route of inbound travel by the fire apparatus
laying the line.
Private hydrants shall be supplied by at least an eight-inch main and hydrants
shall conform to the specifications of hydrants used by the Oregon Water
Division.
Plans for fire lines (water mains) on private property shall be submitted to
the Building and Zoning Inspection Department for approval before installation
is started.
         (Ord. 92-2006. Passed 6-26-06.)
1509.04 ADDITIONAL REQUIREMENTS.
   In addition to the Ohio Fire Code adopted by Section
1509.01, and as amended by Section
1509.03, the following provisions are required:
   (a)   Electrical. Electrical Switch Locks to be Frangible: Where the main
electrical power disconnect device of a building or industrial complex is
locked against unauthorized operation or vandalism, the locking device shall be
frangible, and installed in a manner allowing forcible removal by fire
fighters.
   (b)   Fire Suppression Systems.
      (1)   Connections for Fire Division Use.
         A.   The location of all private fire hydrants and sprinkler/standpipe
Siamese connections shall be approved by the Fire Prevention Bureau prior to
installation. Sprinkler and standpipe connections shall be no farther than 100
feet from a public or private hydrant.
         B.   There shall be no obstruction around a Siamese connection or
between it and the fire hydrant.
         C.   If a Siamese is attached to a building, the wall of the building
shall be constructed of a noncombustible material.
         D.   Siamese and private hydrants shall be protected from damage.
Protective devices shall conform to applicable NFPA standards and shall be
designed and installed in a manner so as not to interfere with or impede the
connection of hoses.
         E.   Siameses shall be of the clapper type with protection plugs.
         F.   Hose threads shall be compatible to Oregon.
         G.   Siameses shall be not less than 18" nor more than 48" above
finished grade.
         H.   Private hydrants shall conform to City standards for public
hydrants. Hydrants shall be located per Fire Prevention Bureau recommendations.
No vehicular parking or other obstructions shall be permitted within 10 feet of
any public or private hydrant.
      (2)   Variances from the standards of paragraph (b)(1) may be granted by
the Building and Zoning Inspection Department when, upon recommendation of the
Fire Prevention Bureau, it is determined that circumstances or conditions
unique to the property, including topographic features of the land on which the
protected structure is located or the relationship of the protected structure
to adjacent uses, would render strict application of the standards
unwarrantedly burdensome without achieving a concomitant benefit to the public
safety.
   (c)   Liquefied Petroleum Gases.
      (1)   Fencing. Fencing shall be required on all L.P.G. installations on
commercial and industrial properties. The fencing shall be chain link fence at
least six (6) feet in height with no slats or other obstructions. The fence
shall be located at least five (5) feet from the tank on all sides. Protective
posts shall be provided when the Bureau of Fire Prevention deems necessary.
      (2)   Portable Trailers. The use of portable LP-Gas trailers for on-site
construction use shall meet all Department of Transportation (DOT) regulations;
proper stop lights and brakes shall be provided. All such trailers shall be
inspected by the Bureau of Fire Prevention.
      (3)   Safety Instructions to Customers. Advice and instructions as to the
safe use of LP-Gas appliances and related equipment shall be provided, in
printed form, to all customers by each LP-Gas dealer, distributor and
installer.
      (4)   Knox Box Entry System. At the discretion of the Fire Prevention
Bureau, a Knox Box Entry System shall be installed on all new commercial
structures. The location of Knox Boxes shall be approved by the Fire Prevention
Bureau.
         (Ord. 92-2006. Passed 6-26-06.)

CHAPTER 1519
Fire Lanes
1519.01   Fire Chief to regulate.

1519.01 FIRE CHIEF TO REGULATE.
   Fire lanes on private property devoted to public use shall be established
under the direction of the Chief of the Fire Division and in accordance with
such regulations as established by the Fire Division with regards to the routes
and the restrictions of parking of vehicles in the area designated as fire
lanes.
(Ord. 172-1972. Passed 10-24-72.)
1519.02 AUTHORITY TO ESTABLISH.
   Where fire lanes have not been established on private property devoted to
public use, and when in the opinion of the Chief of the Fire Division such
lanes should be established, the Fire Division shall have authority to order
fire lanes to be established and maintained by the owners of the property.
(Ord. 172-1972. Passed 10-24-72.)
1519.03 SIGNS.
   It shall be the responsibility of the property owner to cause the erection
of appropriate signs and pavement markings to properly identify the fire lanes;
the signs and pavement markings shall be as approved by the Mayor or his
designee.
(Ord. 172-1972. Passed 10-24-72.)
1519.99 PENALTY.
   (a)   Any person who parks an unattended vehicle in a designated fire lane
as established by this chapter shall be fined ten dollars ($10.00).
 
   (b)   Any person who fails to comply with Section
1519.03 hereof, shall be fined not more than fifty dollars ($50.00).
(Ord. 47-1973. Passed 2-20-73.)

CHAPTER 1529
Identification of Hazardous Chemicals
